title-group.article-title: School District Income Taxes and School Inputs: The Case of Ohio

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2014 Board of Directors of the Journal of Education Finance, Inc.

abstract.p: This study is the first to explore the relationship between school district income taxes and school inputs (expenditures and student–teacher ratios) using Ohio as a case study. The study employed reduced-form expenditure functions on a data panel of 609 school districts between 1990 and 2010. Treating for the endogeneity of school district income taxes, we found that income tax adopters in Ohio spent $0.20 of a dollar of the tax revenue on operating purposes, and they spent four-fifths of this $0.20 on instructional services that were likely to induce gains in student achievement. Also, we found ambiguous evidence on the effect of income tax revenues on student–teacher ratios.

p.mixed-citation: Thirty-seven states provided less funding per pupil to local school districts in 2009 than in 2008 (Oliff and Leachman 2011). In the first quarter of 2012, real local property tax collections across the nation declined for the sixth consecutive quarter, by 2.8% relative to 2011 (Dadayan 2012). Property taxes remain, however, a dominant local source of revenues for school districts. On average, property taxes contributed about 65% of all locally generated education revenue in 2010 and 2011 nationwide (United States Census Bureau 2012,2013).

Although 36 states currently have local option sales taxes (Drenkard 2011), only three states (Georgia, North Carolina, and South Carolina) have allowed school districts to access local option sales taxes (Wang and Zhao 2011).
Philadelphia was the first local government to use local income taxes in 1939 to avoid bankruptcy caused by the Great Depression.
The Ohio Department of Education does not collect data on capital spending. This study, therefore, is unable to examine how income tax revenues affect capital spending.

This study does not examine the effects of local income taxes on student outcomes for two major reasons. First, data on test scores are not available for the first 11 years of our sample period (1990-2010). Second and more important, it is not additional funds, but rather expenditures and how the funds are spent that really matter in raising student outcomes. Traditional education production functions include expenditures (not a variable indicating revenue) as a key explanatory variable.

Districts can put both a property tax reduction (partial or complete) and income tax increase on a single ballot, or income taxes on a separate ballot from that for property taxes. This is different from, for instance, Iowa. School districts in Iowa can use the district income tax funds only to initiate discretionary educational improvement programs as long as there is an accompanying property tax increase.
This section draws partially from Ross and Nguyen-Hoang (2013).

Total district income tax revenues represented only 3.5% of total property taxes in 2010. In addition to property and local income taxes, local revenues may come from tuition payments, fees, sales, and earnings on investments. However, data on these other own-source revenues are not available.
One of the six districts repealed the tax in a referendum in 1986.

Municipalities in Ohio were allowed to levy an income tax much earlier. Toledo was the first to adopt the tax in 1946; other adoptions followed, for example, in Columbus, Springfield, and Youngstown in 1948 and Dayton and Warren in 1949 (Taylor 1962). In 2009, 577 municipalities (236 cities and 341 villages) levied the tax (Ohio Department of Taxation 2011). Also, because a municipality's boundary may overlap or cut across multiple school districts, it appears that municipal income taxes have little bearing on district income taxes.

Earned income is defined as salaries, wages, self-employment income, and other types of employee compensation (e.g. tips), and thus excludes other types of income such as retirement income or lottery winnings. However, as of the end of the 2009 fiscal year, voters in only 19 school districts had approved earned-income-only tax bases (Ohio Department of Taxation, 2010). This small number does not allow for a precise test on potentially differential effects of income tax bases (traditional v. earned income) on educational spending.

The income tax vote is on whether a district will have an income tax at a specified rate. However, before putting the income tax on the ballot, a district's board of education must pass a resolution indicating a specified amount of money to be raised by the tax. A tax commissioner then certifies this resolution and determines the income tax rate. The final resolution available to district residents in an election includes the specified amount to be raised at a specific tax rate.
During this period, only 53 out of 189 district adopters changed their rates, and nearly half of these 53 districts had a standard deviation of 0.25.
Elections can be held in February/March, May, August, or November (the general election).
Only five adopters discontinued the district income tax revenues during our sample period (four districts for one year and one for four years).

Studies that examine how school districts (re)allocate resources in response to accountability ratings (Craig, Imberman, and Perdue 2013), competition from charter schools (Arsen and Ni 2012), or budget référendums (Nguyen-Hoang 2012a) are not discussed.

Another type of own-source revenues for school districts is user fees and charges: lunch fees, transportation fees, book rentals, athletic event admissions, club dues, food sales, and facility leasing. However, they play a minimal role in how schools are funded (Killeen 2007; Wassmer and Fisher 2002).
Flypaper effect refers to the phenomenon in which intergovernmental grants increase public spending by more than an equivalent rise in personal income.
In addition, reduced-form models are easier to grasp, make it easier to identify key parameters of interest, and they require fewer assumptions than structural models (Timmins and Schlenker 2009).

Although fixed effects control for temporally stable efficiency, scholars may use some of the variables in X (e.g., state aid, tax price) to control for efficiency that varies over time (Duncombe and Yinger 2011). For ease of interpretation, the efficiency effects of these variables are disregarded.

A linear trend variable serves to control for common factors that affect all districts and that change at a constant rate year-on-year. Year fixed effects, t, controls for common shocks to all districts in a particular year. Therefore, year fixed effects (conditional on the linear trend) pick up the effects of the common factors that do not change at a constant rate. Several studies (e.g., Autor, 2003), have controlled for both year fixed effects and linear trends.
Another commonly used variable of disadvantaged students is the share of English language learners (ELLs). However, data for this variable are not available between 1990 and 1994.

Some scholars (e.g., Wang, Duncombe, and Yinger 2011) may call this ratio tax share. However, other studies (e.g., Romer and Rosenthal 1982; Santerre 1989) define tax share as median housing price divided by total taxable property (i.e., tax price is equal to tax share times enrollment).

Expenditure and income variables are not log-transformed in equation 1. Using untransformed data facilitates the interpretation of a. Specifically, a now indicates by how much school districts increase expenditures for an additional dollar of income tax revenues. In fact, as presented later, the results are robust to sensitivity tests using log-transformed data.
A time-varying omitted factor that can potentially cause bias is that school districts that adopt income taxes may be faced with greater competition from charter schools (Arsen and Ni 2012).

We did not lag this instrument because we did not want to lose one year of observations, and the results were substantially the same with the lagged IV. Note that the predicted values of the instrument will be the same for any spatial weight matrix which is correlated with the true spatial weight matrix of the data-generating process (LeSage and Pace 2010).

The spatial dispersion of income tax adoptions is presented in Figure 1 of Ross and Nguyen- Hoang (2013). Also, there is no similar phenomenon with any other observable characteristic (e.g., taxable property values, intergovernmental transfers, or income).
Brueckner (2003) provides a review of empirical studies on yardstick competition or other forms of strategic interaction among governments.
A valid IV does not require the effect on the endogenous variable to be uni-directional (Pearl 2009, 247-248).
For ease of discussion, we assume that the average district has the mean values of all the characteristics.
Examples of disabilities are deafness, blindness or visual impairments, speech impairments, and emotional disturbance. A student with disabilities can have multiple disabilities.

The ODE records as free lunch students those who fall into one of the following four categories: (1) they are eligible to receive free lunches through the U.S. Department of Agriculture National School Lunch Program; (2) they reside in a household in which a member is eligible for the school lunch program; (3) they or their guardians are recipients of public assistance; or (4) their guardians meet the income guidelines in their Title 1 applications.
The mean income tax revenue per pupil for adopters only is, however, $854.

Stata, the statistical software we use for empirical work, provides Kleibergen and Papp's (2006) rk statistic in the case of heteroskedasticity and autocorrelation (HAC) standard errors. Critical values to identify weak IVs for endogenous variables with HAC standard errors are, however, still an open area of research. Baum, Schaffer, and Stillman (2007) suggest applying Stock and Yogo's (2005) critical values for the homoscedastic case to the rk statistic with caution. The rk statistic of 620 in column 3 is much larger than the critical value of 11.04 used to reject a 5% maximal relative bias from weak IVs for two endogenous variables. The results in the first stage can be provided upon request.
The coefficient of the common expenditure trend suggests that operating expenditures, on average, increase by $49.3 annually.
In a more common DID specification, the DID estimator is the dummy variable rather than a continuous variable such as I.

Bootstrapping, which was formally introduced in Efron (1979), is a form of resampling the original dataset to produce a series of datasets from which the standard error of an estimate is derived. Block bootstrap, a variant of bootstrap, is done by maintaining the autocorrelation structure of the same group (i.e., school districts) (Bertrand, Duflo, and Mullainathan, 2004).
